This emblem of love the most true,</br>Sweet type of unvarying truth,</br>Enchantingly fair to the view,</br>Was the gift of her favourite youth;</br>Was the myrtle array'd in soft bloom,</br>Sensations of bliss to excite;</br>Round Delia it breath'd its perfume,</br>Was approv'd and preferr'd in her sight.

Did Damon awaken the lyre;</br>Apollo, attach'd to his side,</br>Enliven'd its tremulous wire,</br>Resounding his boast and his pride;</br>For Delia his lays were prolong'd;</br>The myrtle of love was his strain;</br>And much she his suit would have wrong'd,</br>Had she slighted the lays of her swain.

'Mid the warmth of Aurora's first ray</br>The myrtle was seen to expand;</br>Adding sweets to the sweetness of May,</br>Its blossoms invited the hand;</br>And gladly her bard shall repeat,</br>That Delia, due honour to show,</br>Permitted those odours a seat</br>In her bosom, that rivall'd the snow.

Of the vi'let, blue-coated, she sung,</br>As a maiden of diffident mien,</br>The offspring of Flora among,</br>Enriching the Zephyr unseen:</br>Of the rose, so commanding of praise,</br>As the garden's profess'd Columbine,</br>That in blushes too often betrays</br>The shame of her being too fine:

Of the jess'mine, in modest array,</br>For innocent visage admir'd,</br>As chaste and as soft as the day,</br>In stole of Autumnus attir'd;</br>That the suckle, for sympathy fam'd,</br>Her tears would in fragrance distill;</br>That the hyacinth elegance claim'd,</br>As well as the splendid jonquil:

That the cowslip, in gold-colour'd crest,</br>Her breath of ambrosia exhales;</br>With the primrose, less brilliantly drest,</br>And the lily, fair queen of the vales:</br>That geranium, of odours refin'd,</br>And the tulip, variety's friend,</br>Had either its province assign'd,</br>The treasures of Flora to blend:

That the amarinth, deathless of name,</br>In the garden elysian that blew;</br>And the anana, sweetest in fame</br>Of all that e'er blossom'd or grew;</br>That these in successive delight,</br>Alternate their beauties impart;</br>But the myrtle was first in her sight,</br>The object most dear to her heart;

To Venus herself not more dear:</br>—"Then come, honour'd plant, to my breast,"</br>She said — but was pallid with fear,</br>When its foliage she hastily press'd.</br>She saw it recline its gay head,</br>In verdure all wither'd and pale;</br>Its odours, all recently fled,</br>No longer impregnate the gale.

Infelicity, Delia, was thine:</br>Dear mourner, thy sorrows, and grief,</br>Let thy bard with his own intertwine,</br>Administer tender relief.</br>Remember in solace thy swain,</br>To soothe and diminish thy smart,</br>In affection will ever maintain</br>The myrtle of love in thy heart.</br>
